label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, November 1, 1942
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing the events of his previous evening and his birthday, when they visited a new club on the beach and went swimming. Sidney continues in his letter to recount a story of them playing tennis with some friends, a ship that was recently sunk, and the new rules of the Bachelor Officers’  Quarters (BOQ) that prevented them from having supper that evening.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
November 1, 1932
Gertie Darling,
Here I am on my birthday night down at the office
making this typewriter fly in order that I may tell you how much
I love you and missed you on my birXthday. I felt I could take you
in my arms as we talked over the phone, andI could see your sweet
brown eyes, and your hair curling around your ears. I know how
lovely you looked and it gave me the most tremendous desire to take
you by the hand and lead youup to our room. It is so long sincel
I have seen and kissed youthat it seems an eternity. But it will all
be over soon and then we can make up for everything we have missed.
Last night we went to Kanaoe . There is the most
attracetive club there. Absolutely sweet. A tiny frame building
built in the simplies_t manner possible. Two sides are all sliding
glass doors and one of these doors open out onto a swimming pool.
The other opens onto a tennis court which is sorrounded by cocanut
palms, and flowering habicus. There is the most attractive bar
by the swimming pool. Nothing is served there except ice water,
but it is so cunning that I loved it. We played tennis and then
metered to the BOQ at the air field for dinner. The food w s very
good and it was served by negroes that were so blacked and loose
jointed that I felt the[y] had just come off theplantation. We
had baked ham and yams and ice tea, and I ate so much that my sides
swelled out like a ballons. Afterwards we motored back over the
Pali, which is a most terrifying experience in the blackout and
were in bed by ten clock. This morning , my birthday morning I
[End Page 1]
awoke quite early[,] asper habit and read , delighted that I did not
have toget up and go to work. At eight I ordered the most enormous
breakfast sent to our rooms, read the morningpaper and then your
call came through. For half [A]n hour[,] after talking to you I did
not make much sense, just sort of wandered around the room puttering
with cleaning shoes looking at your picture, cleaning shoes again
until finally I pulled myself out of the daze ard kicked Morris out
of bed. We then got Teddy Burrell and a boy called Pick Butler one
played doubles. It was great fun , they were to good for us[,] and
youth told, so we went down to defeat. I then lay on the beach for
an hour during which I slipped into the water a couple of times.
However the Water was no t very good because it was filled with
big globs of oil that touched and stuck so that at the end I looked
likea negro and had a hell of a time getting it off. Thebeach was
followed by a big lunch and a rest on our porch during which I
read the account of the sinking of the wasp by the men cn board.
I know you have read it so will not send it to you. without a
doubt it is the most terryfying discription of men going to their
death in the sheeet of fire that engulfed the ship that I have ever
read. The poor fellows that were trapped below andthe men who
lost their lives trying to rescue them nade one realize how brave
those sailors and officers were.
Afterwards we played tennis again and then dressed
and came to the yard with the idea of having dinner at the BOQ.
What was our dismay on arriving there to find a sign saying ["] we
have adopted the principle that after xxx two hundred and fifty
men have been served the dinning room will be closed.["] So now
I am at the office dinnerless and hungry as hell. Bet I will eat
[End Page 2]
enough breakfast to send that place into bankruptcy. I am already
thinking ofthe scrambled eggs and hot cakes. WE came here to night[,]
because we find that after sunday[,] monday has such an accumalation of
work that it is better to come down Sunday night and work for
a couple of hours in order to lessen the londay morning rush.
I received a cable from you this evening wishing me
a happy birthday and saying you were telehoning me at 9AM . Of 
course that was the telephone call of this xxxx morning. I however
had had previous experience with these calls and had called the
operator of overseas calls on Saturday and toldher I wasexpecting
a call and to let me know that evening tu the latest nt what time
I might expect it.
[T]he last letter I received from you was that of
the thirteenthX of October. I think there has been some delay on
the mainl,and because all the men have had the same trouble and
many of them say they are going to marry stenographers before the
next war in o[r]der that they may be sure of getting letters.
Sammy Trincher tele[P]honed Morris yesterday saying that
he was being drafted but Pearl would run the theatres in
conjunction with MucK. It would be very funny if those two girls 
ran it hotter than the men. No one would dare to lift their heads
again. I am afraid however they are not hard boiled enough to do
the bargaining for pictures or fight the jews at all the little
tricks of the trade. It would really be a shame if some kike
stopped in and got all the good pictures from Morris while he is at
war.
Have not heard a word from Armsnt so figure he has passed
us by and is ["]down under["] All my love.
Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 3]
